DOC.TEXT: The stock market gained ground today, bidding again to mount a yearend rally. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials climbed 18.34 to 2,727.60 by noontime today on Wall Street. Gainers outnumbered losers by more than 3 to 2 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 763 up, 479 down and 562 unchanged. Analysts found little in the economic news to stir the market out of its recent lethargy. Interest rates were narrowly mixed in the credit markets. But traders still appeared to be hopeful that stocks might gather strength in early 1990, once yearend maneuvering by investors for tax and portfolio reporting purposes is out of the way. Germany Fund jumped 1\ to 16[ as the West German market soared to new highs, propelled by enthusiasm over the ascendance of democracy in Eastern Europe. Gainers among the blue chips included Philip Morris, up \ at 40\; Merck, up \ at 76; Sears Roebuck, up { at 37~; International Business Machines, up } at 95\, and General Electric, up { at 63~. Hilton Hotels fell 5 to 84} on a report that efforts to sell the company had attracted lower bids than had been predicted. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose .83 to 192.55. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up .65 at 371.45. Volume on the Big Board came to 58.95 million shares at noontime, against 35.37 million at the same point Tuesday.
